{"abstract": "JPMorgan Chase nears $2 billion settlement in Madoff Case. | Men\u2019s Wearhouse starts hostile bid. | Investors are pouring money into start-ups, eclipsing the exuberance of the dot-com era more than a decade ago. | The S.E.C. announces a departure.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2014/01/06/morning-agenda-jpmorgan-near-a-settlement-in-madoff-case/", "snippet": "JPMorgan Chase nears $2 billion settlement in Madoff Case. | Men\u2019s Wearhouse starts hostile bid. | Investors are pouring money into start-ups, eclipsing the exuberance of the dot-com era more than a decade ago. | The S.E.C. announces a departure.", "lead_paragraph": "JPMorgan Chase is starting the year the same way it ended the last one: by whipping out its wallet, Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Ben Protess report in DealBook. The bank is preparing to reach roughly $2 billion in criminal and civil settlements with federal authorities who claim that it ignored signs of Bernard L. Madoff\u2019s huge Ponzi scheme, bringing its settlement total to nearly $20 billion over the last year. The settlements come on the heels of a record $13 billion deal with the Justice Department in November related to the bank\u2019s questionable mortgage practices leading up to the financial crisis.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "JPMorgan Near a Settlement in Madoff Case", "kicker": "DealBook", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [], "pub_date": "2014-01-06T14:19:19+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Sydney Ember", "person": [{"firstname": "Sydney", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Ember", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/7b24810b-1590-5380-9c98-73b0ed505397", "word_count": 1995, "uri": "nyt://article/7b24810b-1590-5380-9c98-73b0ed505397"}

{"abstract": "Fines for banks\u2019 role in mortgage crisis could total nearly $50 billion, not including JPMorgan\u2019s settlement. | Ex-SAC trader falsified grades at Harvard. | A storied Washington law firm looks to merge. | Snapchat says sorry.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2014/01/10/morning-agenda-banks-brace-for-reckoning/", "snippet": "Fines for banks\u2019 role in mortgage crisis could total nearly $50 billion, not including JPMorgan\u2019s settlement. | Ex-SAC trader falsified grades at Harvard. | A storied Washington law firm looks to merge. | Snapchat says sorry.", "lead_paragraph": "When the dust has settled on investigations into the role of banks in the mortgage crisis, fines could total nearly $50 billion, and that does not include the $13 billion that JPMorgan Chase agreed to pay, Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Peter Eavis report in DealBook. {"abstract": "JPMorgan Chase and Wells Fargo, set to report fourth-quarter results on Tuesday, will kick off a flurry of bank earnings, and Intel will post its fourth-quarter results.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2014/01/13/business/economic-reports-for-the-week-of-jan-13.html", "snippet": "JPMorgan Chase and Wells Fargo, set to report fourth-quarter results on Tuesday, will kick off a flurry of bank earnings, and Intel will post its fourth-quarter results.", "lead_paragraph": "BANK EARNINGS JPMorgan Chase and Wells Fargo, set to report fourth-quarter results on Tuesday, will kick off a flurry of bank earnings. The banking giants, analysts say, will most likely face sluggish demand from borrowers whose appetite for refinancing has been sapped by rising rates. For JPMorgan Chase, the nation\u2019s largest bank, the quarterly report comes after a string of costly government settlements, prompting analysts to predict that high legal costs could hamper profit. All told, JPMorgan will have paid some $20 billion to resolve government investigations in the last 12 months alone. {"abstract": "JPMorgan Chase is trying to stop a shareholder\u2019s proposal from going to a vote at its annual meeting.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2014/03/02/business/break-up-the-bank-its-not-for-you-to-ask.html", "snippet": "JPMorgan Chase is trying to stop a shareholder\u2019s proposal from going to a vote at its annual meeting.", "lead_paragraph": "JPMorgan Chase is trying to put its troubles behind it. {"abstract": "Berkshire Hathaway posted a record profit in 2013. | Tensions in Ukraine rattle global financial markets. | A Mexican unit of Citigroup was defrauded of as much as $400 million. | A JPMorgan Chase shareholder has introduced a proposal to break up the bank. | Mt. Gox and a steady erosion of faith in the Bitcoin community.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2014/03/03/morning-agenda-a-record-profit-for-berkshire/", "snippet": "Berkshire Hathaway posted a record profit in 2013. | Tensions in Ukraine rattle global financial markets. | A Mexican unit of Citigroup was defrauded of as much as $400 million. | A JPMorgan Chase shareholder has introduced a proposal to break up ...", "lead_paragraph": "Berkshire Hathaway, run by Warren E. Buffett, released its annual report on Saturday, disclosing a record profit in 2013 of $19.5 billion, a 32 percent increase from $14.8 billion in 2012. Berkshire\u2019s book value per share \u2014 the measure Mr. Buffett uses to assess the company\u2019s performance \u2014 rose 18.2 percent in 2013, much less than the 32.4 percent rise in the Standard & Poor\u2019s 500-stock index. But even as Berkshire posts handsome results, it remains to be seen whether it can continue to make large acquisitions that will help it sustain its reputation as the nation\u2019s savviest investor, Peter Eavis and Rachel Abrams write in DealBook.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "A Record Profit for Berkshire", "kicker": "DealBook", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [], "pub_date": "2014-03-03T12:50:52+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Sydney Ember", "person": [{"firstname": "Sydney", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Ember", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/b7c9de7f-ea59-52cc-b367-cf432a909709", "word_count": 2542, "uri": "nyt://article/b7c9de7f-ea59-52cc-b367-cf432a909709"}

{"abstract": "Facebook to buy Oculus, a maker of a virtual reality headset. | A likely heir is leaving JPMorgan Chase. | The maker of Candy Crush is set to trade on the N.Y.S.E. | The Murdochs take a step in succession planning.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2014/03/26/morning-agenda-facebooks-2-billion-deal-for-oculus/", "snippet": "Facebook to buy Oculus, a maker of a virtual reality headset. | A likely heir is leaving JPMorgan Chase. | The maker of Candy Crush is set to trade on the N.Y.S.E. | The Murdochs take a step in succession planning.", "lead_paragraph": "In a surprise move, Facebook announced on Tuesday that it had reached a $2 billion agreement to buy Oculus VR, the maker of a virtual reality headset, in a bet that technology commonly associated with science fiction can help eventually turn social networking into an immersive 3-D experience, Nick Wingfield and Vindu Goel write in The New York Times. The announcement comes just over a month after Facebook made waves by revealing it would buy the mobile messaging app WhatsApp for up to $19 billion.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Facebook\u2019s $2 Billion Deal for Oculus", "kicker": "DealBook", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [], "pub_date": "2014-03-26T12:45:12+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Sydney Ember", "person": [{"firstname": "Sydney", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Ember", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/7500cf0c-d83c-5691-83e7-9c0b01931900", "word_count": 2354, "uri": "nyt://article/7500cf0c-d83c-5691-83e7-9c0b01931900"}

{"abstract": "Jamie Dimon has throat cancer. | Puerto Rico\u2019s power utility is struggling to pay its debts. | A single bidder won a Bitcoin auction by the U.S. Marshals Service. | Pershing Square has hired Credit Suisse as an adviser in its fight with Allergan.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2014/07/02/morning-agenda-jpmorgan-chief-has-curable-cancer/", "snippet": "Jamie Dimon has throat cancer. | Puerto Rico\u2019s power utility is struggling to pay its debts. | A single bidder won a Bitcoin auction by the U.S. Marshals Service. | Pershing Square has hired Credit Suisse as an adviser in its fight with Allergan.", "lead_paragraph": "Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, said on Tuesday in a note to the bank\u2019s employees and shareholders that he had throat cancer and would begin treatment shortly at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, DealBook\u2019s Jessica Silver-Greenberg writes. Doctors discovered the cancer at an early stage, Mr. Dimon said, noting that his condition was \u201ccurable.\u201d Moreover, he said doctors had confirmed that the cancer had not spread beyond the \u201coriginal site\u201d and the adjacent lymph nodes on the right side of his neck. He described the prognosis from the doctors as \u201cexcellent.\u201d", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Morning Agenda: JPMorgan Chief Has \u2018Curable\u2019 Cancer", "kicker": "DealBook", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [], "pub_date": "2014-07-02T11:20:02+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Sydney Ember", "person": [{"firstname": "Sydney", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Ember", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/d57864cd-ed97-5c35-9b92-aaff4c82011b", "word_count": 1743, "uri": "nyt://article/d57864cd-ed97-5c35-9b92-aaff4c82011b"}

{"abstract": "Jamie Dimon is the latest leader to disclose an illness. | The venture capitalist Tim Draper won the Bitcoin auction. | A judge has narrowed the insider trading case against Rengan Rajaratnam. | Tyson has reached a deal for Hillshire.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2014/07/03/morning-agenda-when-the-c-e-o-gets-sick/", "snippet": "Jamie Dimon is the latest leader to disclose an illness. | The venture capitalist Tim Draper won the Bitcoin auction. | A judge has narrowed the insider trading case against Rengan Rajaratnam. | Tyson has reached a deal for Hillshire.", "lead_paragraph": "Corporate leaders from Steven P. Jobs to Warren E. Buffett and now Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, have wrestled with how \u2012 or whether \u2012 to go public about health problems, Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Julie Creswell write in DealBook. How much to disclose, and when, involves delicate corporate and personal decisions for which there are few hard rules. Executives have no real legal obligation to tell the world they are sick.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Morning Agenda: When the C.E.O. {"abstract": "Argentina has spent years battling a group of hedge funds that want full payment on bonds that defaulted in 2001. Some answers to questions about the dispute.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2014/07/30/q-a-whats-behind-the-battle-over-argentinas-debt/", "snippet": "Argentina has spent years battling a group of hedge funds that want full payment on bonds that defaulted in 2001. Some answers to questions about the dispute.", "lead_paragraph": "Argentina is on the verge of defaulting on billions of dollars of government debt. It has reached this point after years of battling a group of New York hedge funds that have been demanding full payment on bonds that defaulted in 2001. The battle has already rocked international debts markets and may affect the economies of other countries in the future. {"abstract": "JPMorgan Chase and other United States banks struck by cyberattack. | Alibaba\u2019s profit soared. | Lending Club filed to go public. | Still work to be done to hold corporate malefactors accountable.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2014/08/28/morning-agenda-hackers-hit-u-s-banks/", "snippet": "JPMorgan Chase and other United States banks struck by cyberattack. | Alibaba\u2019s profit soared. | Lending Club filed to go public. | Still work to be done to hold corporate malefactors accountable.", "lead_paragraph": "A number of United States banks, including JPMorgan Chase and at least four others, were struck by hackers in a series of coordinated attacks this month, according to four people briefed on a continuing investigation into the crimes, Nicole Perlroth writes in The New York Times. The hackers infiltrated the banks\u2019 networks, siphoning off gigabytes of data, including checking and savings account information, in what security experts described as a sophisticated cyberattack. The motivation and origin of the attacks are not yet clear, according to investigators.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Morning Agenda: Hackers Hit U.S. Banks", "kicker": "DealBook", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [], "pub_date": "2014-08-28T11:32:57+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Sydney Ember", "person": [{"firstname": "Sydney", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Ember", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/e37ee9ae-3541-5245-8a9f-af36770efe79", "word_count": 2047, "uri": "nyt://article/e37ee9ae-3541-5245-8a9f-af36770efe79"}

{"abstract": "AbbVie walks away from its bid to acquire Shire. | JPMorgan cyberattack also hit its race website. | Fear returns to Wall Street.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2014/10/16/morning-agenda-abbvies-cold-feet/", "snippet": "AbbVie walks away from its bid to acquire Shire. | JPMorgan cyberattack also hit its race website. | Fear returns to Wall Street.", "lead_paragraph": "The Obama administration\u2019s effort to curb maneuvers known as tax inversions has essentially killed the biggest corporate takeover of the year, DealBook\u2019s David Gelles writes. In the wake of new rules penalizing such inversions, AbbVie has walked away from its bid to acquire the Irish drug maker Shire for $54 billion. Late Wednesday, AbbVie, based in Illinois, said it would recommend that its shareholders vote against approving the deal in the event that it is put to a vote. In particular, AbbVie indicated that the new Treasury rules, which targeted the ability of companies that moved abroad to use overseas cash on a tax-free basis, had made the deal for Shire less financially attractive. The news sent shares of Shire tumbling in London.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Morning Agenda: AbbVie\u2019s Cold Feet", "kicker": "DealBook", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [], "pub_date": "2014-10-16T12:20:27+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Sydney Ember", "person": [{"firstname": "Sydney", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Ember", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/cd99f7dd-d01b-5ff8-85b9-a4bb6163bfc7", "word_count": 1892, "uri": "nyt://article/cd99f7dd-d01b-5ff8-85b9-a4bb6163bfc7"}

{"abstract": "Federal authorities are stepping up efforts to fortify big banks against cyberattacks. | States are easing laws that helped poor borrowers. | Google places a big bet on augmented reality. | Amgen is under pressure to break up.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2014/10/22/morning-agenda-push-to-bolster-banks-cyberdefenses/", "snippet": "Federal authorities are stepping up efforts to fortify big banks against cyberattacks. | States are easing laws that helped poor borrowers. | Google places a big bet on augmented reality. | Amgen is under pressure to break up.", "lead_paragraph": "Federal and state authorities are stepping up efforts to fortify banks and brokerage firms after this summer\u2019s cyberattack on JPMorgan Chase and a dozen other financial institutions, Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Matthew Goldstein report in DealBook. Top officials at the Treasury Department are said to be discussing the need to improve a critical area of cybersecurity: outside vendors, including law firms, accounting and marketing firms and even janitorial companies. Under discussion is a requirement that the banks put in place more stringent procedures and safeguards to make sure the outside firms have, at the least, basic defenses.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Morning Agenda: Push to Bolster Banks\u2019 Cyberdefenses", "kicker": "DealBook", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [], "pub_date": "2014-10-22T11:39:28+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Sydney Ember", "person": [{"firstname": "Sydney", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Ember", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/29a2fba5-a9cf-521a-bdb4-766c8e9bc3dd", "word_count": 2318, "uri": "nyt://article/29a2fba5-a9cf-521a-bdb4-766c8e9bc3dd"}

{"abstract": "Over the last decade, the managing director of DBL Investors, Nancy Pfund, has quietly built a reputation as the go-to venture capitalist for companies looking to make a social impact.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2014/10/27/a-track-record-for-making-money-and-making-a-difference/", "snippet": "Over the last decade, the managing director of DBL Investors, Nancy Pfund, has quietly built a reputation as the go-to venture capitalist for companies looking to make a social impact.", "lead_paragraph": "When the co-founders of SolarCity, Lyndon and Peter Rive, along with their cousin Elon Musk, were raising money for their solar energy start-up in 2007, they called on just one outside investor. {"abstract": "Sex and drug claims at Jefferies draw a risky retort. | JPMorgan lifts its estimate for legal costs. | Tough quarter for Sprint highlights lost promise of T-Mobile US deal.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2014/11/04/morning-agenda-sex-drugs-and-investment-banking/", "snippet": "Sex and drug claims at Jefferies draw a risky retort. | JPMorgan lifts its estimate for legal costs. | Tough quarter for Sprint highlights lost promise of T-Mobile US deal.", "lead_paragraph": "An investment bank has taken unusual steps to quell any idea that it tolerates drug use or promiscuous activity. In response to scandalous accusations made against a managing director, Sage Kelly, as part of a divorce and custody filing, Richard B. Handler, the chief executive of Jefferies, has defended Mr. Kelly, made an impassioned case that his firm was being unfairly smeared and ended up marching an army of bankers into a drug test in the middle of the day after approaching other members of Mr. Kelly\u2019s team, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in the DealBook Column. Mr. Kelly was accused by his wife, Christina, of abusing drugs, including cocaine and ecstasy. She also contended that Mr. Kelly instigated a sexual encounter involving a client, Marc Beer, and his girlfriend.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Morning Agenda: Sex, Drugs and Investment Banking", "kicker": "DealBook", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [], "pub_date": "2014-11-04T12:29:55+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Sydney Ember", "person": [{"firstname": "Sydney", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Ember", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/b2829c4b-5216-5b7e-becc-46161423c069", "word_count": 2208, "uri": "nyt://article/b2829c4b-5216-5b7e-becc-46161423c069"}

{"abstract": "Companies still need to invest in cyberprotection and detection, says Richard Beales of Reuters Breakingviews.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2014/12/23/the-need-for-bank-cyberinsurance/", "snippet": "Companies still need to invest in cyberprotection and detection, says Richard Beales of Reuters Breakingviews.", "lead_paragraph": "A high-profile hack at JPMorgan \u00a0Chase \u2013 to say nothing of monstrous breaches at Sony and Home Depot \u2013 has made cybersecurity a daily concern for executives at big banks and corporations. One partial protection is to take out insurance. It\u2019s a confusing market, but growing fast. With a United States government campaign on top of all the publicity, coverage may become standard.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "The Need for Bank Cyberinsurance", "kicker": "DealBook", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Banking and Financial Institutions", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Computer Security", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Insurance", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Home Depot Inc", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "JPMorgan Chase & Company", "rank": 5, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Sony Corporation", "rank": 6, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2014-12-23T19:40:06+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Richard Beales", "person": [{"firstname": "Richard", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Beales", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/6f1bb55c-3018-5110-bede-133eae3ae747", "word_count": 447, "uri": "nyt://article/6f1bb55c-3018-5110-bede-133eae3ae747"}

{"abstract": "The Justice Department is pushing banks to plead guilty to settle a currency inquiry. | A disproportionate number of companies led by women are the targets of activist investors. | Puerto Rico\u2019s debt plan is in jeopardy. | Profit at UBS rises.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2015/02/10/morning-agenda-u-s-presses-banks-for-guilty-pleas/", "snippet": "The Justice Department is pushing banks to plead guilty to settle a currency inquiry. | A disproportionate number of companies led by women are the targets of activist investors. | Puerto Rico\u2019s debt plan is in jeopardy. | Profit at UBS rises.", "lead_paragraph": "U.S. SEEKS FELONY PLEAS BY BIG BANKS | The Justice Department is pushing some of the biggest banks on Wall Street, including American institutions, to plead guilty to criminal charges that they manipulated the prices of foreign currencies, Ben Protess and Jessica Silver-Greenberg report in DealBook. In the final stages of a long-running investigation into corruption in the world\u2019s biggest financial market, federal prosecutors have recently informed Barclays, JPMorgan Chase, the Royal Bank of Scotland and Citigroup that they must enter guilty pleas to settle the cases, according to lawyers briefed on the matter. ", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Morning Agenda: U.S. Presses Banks for Guilty Pleas", "kicker": "DealBook", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [], "pub_date": "2015-02-10T12:21:59+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Sydney Ember", "person": [{"firstname": "Sydney", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Ember", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/50d9c936-ea11-510b-85e7-28ed1b80fbf5", "word_count": 2273, "uri": "nyt://article/50d9c936-ea11-510b-85e7-28ed1b80fbf5"}

{"abstract": "As foreign investors clamored for a piece of China\u2019s real estate boom, it was easy to overlook the type of risk that brought down the property developer Kaisa.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2015/03/15/business/dealbook/in-china-a-building-frenzys-fault-lines.html", "snippet": "As foreign investors clamored for a piece of China\u2019s real estate boom, it was easy to overlook the type of risk that brought down the property developer Kaisa.", "lead_paragraph": "As the real estate market in the United States was collapsing in the mid-2000s, Wall Street went in search of new terrain, and found it in China. All across the country, from Beijing to Shenzhen, sprawling housing developments and business districts were popping up, seemingly overnight. Real estate prices were soaring. {"abstract": "The drop comes as the bank prepares this year to replace its chief executive with William T. {"abstract": "If companies are going to fight activist investors who call for breakups or spinoffs, they should also be more honest about downsides of mergers.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2015/06/03/business/dealbook/breaking-up-companies-creates-extensive-costs-too.html", "snippet": "If companies are going to fight activist investors who call for breakups or spinoffs, they should also be more honest about downsides of mergers.", "lead_paragraph": "Acquisitive corporate chieftains love to talk about \u201csynergies\u201d from the deals they\u2019re planning while they de-emphasize costs. On the flip side, managers who are trying to resist pressure to split their companies may overstate the \u201cdis-synergies\u201d such moves would create, but such costs are still real.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Breaking Up Companies Creates Extensive Costs, Too", "kicker": "Breakingviews", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "organizations", "value": "Pfizer Inc", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "JPMorgan Chase & Company", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2015-06-02T18:11:54+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "DealBook", "byline": {"original": "By Robert Cyran and Richard Beales", "person": [{"firstname": "Robert", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Cyran", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}, {"firstname": "Richard", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Beales", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 2}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/1a6c5508-6c52-531b-add0-4c306893a29a", "word_count": 371, "uri": "nyt://article/1a6c5508-6c52-531b-add0-4c306893a29a"}

{"abstract": "The firm\u2019s quarterly results could offer some insight into just how much the Volcker Rule helps or hinders investment banks in volatile markets.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/10/business/dealbook/jefferies-may-be-canary-in-wall-streets-shuttered-mine.html", "snippet": "The firm\u2019s quarterly results could offer some insight into just how much the Volcker Rule helps or hinders investment banks in volatile markets.", "lead_paragraph": "As markets whipsawed last month, a dubious meme made the rounds on Wall Street. If big banks like Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan Chase could put their own capital to work, investors would not have endured so much volatility, or so the thinking went. But thanks to new regulations in the Dodd-Frank Act, they had to sit idly by, unable to either profit much or lend a hand.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Jefferies May Be Canary in Wall Street\u2019s Shuttered Mine", "kicker": "Breakingviews", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Banking and Financial Institutions", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Jefferies Group Inc", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2015-09-09T17:33:15+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "DealBook", "byline": {"original": "By Antony Currie", "person": [{"firstname": "Antony", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Currie", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/5ceed340-ca2c-5478-99a4-a060a3ad387b", "word_count": 405, "uri": "nyt://article/5ceed340-ca2c-5478-99a4-a060a3ad387b"}

{"abstract": "Cutting costs and eliminating huge legal bills have helped the bank, but its rivals are ahead on efficiency, among other areas.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2015/10/15/business/dealbook/bank-of-americas-hunt-for-growth.html", "snippet": "Cutting costs and eliminating huge legal bills have helped the bank, but its rivals are ahead on efficiency, among other areas.", "lead_paragraph": "Wells Fargo and JPMorgan have reported third-quarter results that highlight a $7 billion challenge for rival Bank of America. That\u2019s the extra annual profit the lender run by Brian Moynihan would need to earn for a 10 percent return on equity, generally the level at which big banks cover their cost of capital. Cutting spending to match Wells Fargo\u2019s efficient operation would not quite suffice, though. And JPMorgan proved on Tuesday that it can manage passable results even when revenue falls.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Bank of America\u2019s Hunt for Growth", "kicker": "Breakingviews", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "organizations", "value": "Bank of America Corporation", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "JPMorgan Chase & Company", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Wells Fargo & Company", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Banking and Financial Institutions", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}, {"name": "persons", "value": "Moynihan, Brian T", "rank": 5, "major": "N"}, {"name": "persons", "value": "Dimon, James", "rank": 6, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Company Reports", "rank": 7, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2015-10-15T01:55:57+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "DealBook", "byline": {"original": "By Antony Currie", "person": [{"firstname": "Antony", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Currie", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/3073b9ef-3f52-579d-82ce-c0def54c8a0c", "word_count": 399, "uri": "nyt://article/3073b9ef-3f52-579d-82ce-c0def54c8a0c"}

{"abstract": "A fourth-quarter fizzle for most large banks is followed by a steep drop in their market value in the first two weeks of the first quarter.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2016/01/16/business/dealbook/rocky-road-ahead-for-big-banks.html", "snippet": "A fourth-quarter fizzle for most large banks is followed by a steep drop in their market value in the first two weeks of the first quarter.", "lead_paragraph": "America\u2019s too-big-to-fail cabal is nursing $130 billion in damages. {"abstract": "In the book, she describes the ruthless ambition that affected the people close to her and tries to make amends for her years of boorish behavior.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/14/business/dealbook/in-memoir-erin-callan-steps-back-from-lehman-legacy.html", "snippet": "In the book, she describes the ruthless ambition that affected the people close to her and tries to make amends for her years of boorish behavior.", "lead_paragraph": "In May 2008, two months after Bear Stearns collapsed into the arms of JPMorgan Chase, sending paroxysms of fear from one end of Wall Street to the other, I had lunch with Erin Callan, who was then in her fifth month as the chief financial officer of Lehman Brothers. {"abstract": "In a series of meetings, titans of business and finance grappled with what they see as a problem of too much money going and staying private.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2016/07/21/business/dealbook/ceos-meet-in-secret-over-sorry-state-of-public-companies.html", "snippet": "In a series of meetings, titans of business and finance grappled with what they see as a problem of too much money going and staying private.", "lead_paragraph": "Warren E. Buffett quietly walked through the lobby of JPMorgan Chase\u2019s headquarters on Park Avenue in Manhattan last summer and was ushered up to the 49th floor by a security guard, trying to avoid drawing too much attention. Laurence D. Fink, chairman of BlackRock, the world\u2019s largest money manager \u2014 with more than $4 trillion \u2014 soon was also escorted upstairs. Abby Johnson, the chief executive of Fidelity (which invests more than $2 trillion), and Frederick William McNabb III, chief of Vanguard ($3 trillion), were also shepherded to the elevator.", {"abstract": "Wall Street banks are seeking until 2022 to offload investments banned by the rule, but the effort makes them appear to be trying to avoid oversight.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2016/08/13/business/dealbook/foot-dragging-on-volcker-rule-gives-banks-critics-ammunition.html", "snippet": "Wall Street banks are seeking until 2022 to offload investments banned by the rule, but the effort makes them appear to be trying to avoid oversight.", "lead_paragraph": "Wall Street\u2019s procrastination only gives opponents another reason to act. Goldman Sachs, JPMorgan Chase, Morgan Stanley and other banks want the Federal Reserve to give them until 2022 to offload investments banned by the Volcker Rule. They have already had six years to do so, during which time the stock market has doubled. Asking for such a long delay may lead to unwanted consequences.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Foot-Dragging on Volcker Rule Gives Banks\u2019 Critics Ammunition", "kicker": "Breakingviews", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "Banks\u2019 Bid to Delay Volcker Rule Compliance Encourages Foes", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Regulation and Deregulation of Industry", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Goldman Sachs Group Inc", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Morgan Stanley", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "JPMorgan Chase & Company", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)", "rank": 5, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2016-08-12T20:43:32+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "DealBook", "byline": {"original": "By Antony Currie", "person": [{"firstname": "Antony", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Currie", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/a32edad8-dedc-5f33-bfb2-a78f7ee8cf6d", "word_count": 276, "uri": "nyt://article/a32edad8-dedc-5f33-bfb2-a78f7ee8cf6d"}
